This is why Annick has been selling maize and various other products (soap, sugar, biscuits, etc) from her home for 10 years now.  She buys her supplies at a market in Benin.  

In order to strengthen her business, Annick has joined with the other members of her group to request this first loan from the field partner Alidé .

loans.use: to buy maize and other products (such as soap, sugar and biscuits).

loans.name: Afepeb 2 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe AFEPEB 2 est composé de deux personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, nommée Blandine Léonie(celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 61 ans. Blandine Léonie a très peu fréquenté. Blandine Léonie est veuve avec deux enfants, tous scolarisés et un reste à sa charge. Blandine Léonie vit avec ses enfants . Les diverses charges de la famille sont supportées par Blandine Léonie. Dans le but, d'assumer ses responsabilités Blandine Léonie vend depuis trente cinq ans de la nourriture( riz accompagné de sauce et de poisson)dans sa région. De façon secondaire, Blandine Léonie vend des tissus par la méthode de distribution. Blandine Léonie s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité, Blandine Léonie s’associe aux autres membres du groupe AFEPEB 2 pour solliciter un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
Afepeb 2 is a group made up of 2 people who live in the same district. The group's representative, Blandine Léonie (the one with her hand raised in the picture) is 61 years old. Blandine Léonie did not get much schooling. She is a widow with 2 children, both of whom have attended school and one of whom remains in her care. Blandine Léonie lives with her child and covers the family's various expenses.

In order to be able to assume her responsibilities, Blandine Léonie has been selling prepared food (rice with fish and sauce) for 35 years in her region. She also sells fabrics via the distribution channel. Blandine Léonie gets her supplies at a market in Benin. Blandine Léonie joins the other member of the Afepeb 2 group in requesting a 4th loan from ALIDé, with the aim of strengthening her business. The previous loans have been properly repaid.

loans.use: to buy food items (rice, condiments and vegetable oil) and fabrics.

loans.name: Erika Alejandra

texts.es: Erika es una joven emprendedora de 23 años de edad que se dedica a la confección desde el año 2011. Aprendió la labor por medio de la observación y vio en esta actividad una oportunidad de negocio rentable, por lo que inició su propio taller con la ayuda de su esposo que se desempeña como docente. Con el apoyo de un crédito anterior compró su primera máquina con la que comenzó a desarrollar su actividad y poco a poco, gracias a su trabajo diario, fue mejorando su técnica y su destreza. Actualmente solicita su segundo ciclo crediticio con el que desea comprar una máquina fileteadora e insumos al por mayor (telas, hilos, botones, resortes), con esto podrá mejorar las condiciones de trabajo y disminuirá el tiempo de producción aumentando su eficiencia, lo que se reflejará en más ventas y mejores ingresos, con los que podrá continuar aportando a la economía de su hogar y además avanzará para cumplir el sueño de hacer crecer su negocio hasta convertirse en una mayorista de telas y confección. Erika es consciente que para lograr sus objetivos debe trabajar con mucha disciplina, dedicación y empeño, sólo así podrá tener la calidad de vida que desea disfrutar al lado de su pareja.
texts.en:
Erika, 23, is a young entrepreneur who has been in the sewing business since 2011.  She learned her trade through observation and thought it would be a good opportunity for a profitable business.  She set up her own sewing shop with the help of her husband who works as a teacher.  With a previous loan she was able to buy her first sewing machine and started her activity little by little.  Thanks to her daily efforts she has been able to improve her technique and skill.

She is currently requesting her second loan to buy an overlock sewing machine and wholesale supplies (fabrics, threads, buttons, snaps) so she can improve her work conditions and cut back on production time.  This will increase her efficiency, sales volume and income so she can continue contributing to the household economy and strive toward her goal of expanding busines and becoming a fabric and dressmaking wholesale dealer.   Erika is conscious that in order to meet her goals she must work with discipline, dedication and drive because it is the only way she and her husband will have a quality lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy an overlock sewing machine and wholesale supplies (fabrics, threads, buttons, snaps).

loans.name: Gnambossou Gbeta 5 Group

texts.fr: GNAMBOSSOU GBETA 5 est un groupe composé de deux personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, nommée Dossi Jeanne (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 61 ans. Dossi Jeanne a fréquenté l'école jusqu'au secondaire. Dossi Jeanne est mariée à un revendeur du nom de Gustave. Le couple a cinq enfants, tous scolarisés et trois à leur charge. Dossi Jeanne vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges de la famille. Pour ce faire, Dossi Jeanne vend depuis trente ans du maïs, du haricot et du gari (farine de manioc)à son domicile. Dossi Jeanne s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité, Dossi Jeanne s’associe aux autres membres du groupe GNAMBOSSOU GBETA 5 pour solliciter un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: Gnambossou Gbeta 5 is a group made up of 2 people who live in the same district. The group's representative, Dossi Jeanne (the one with her hand raised in the picture), is 61 years old. Dossi Jeanne left school at secondary level. She is married to a retailer called Gustave. The couple have 5 children, all of whom attend/have attended school and 3 of whom are still in their care. Dossi Jeanne lives with her husband and their children. The couple both cover the family's various expenses. In order to be able to do this, Dossi Jeanne has been selling maize, beans and gari (cassava flour) from her home for 30 years. Dossi Jeanne gets her supplies at a market in Benin. Dossi Jeanne joins the other member of the Gnambossou Gbeta 5 group in requesting a 4th loan from ALIDé, with the aim of strengthening her business. The previous loans have been correctly repaid.

loans.use: to buy maize, beans and gari (cassava flour).

loans.name: María Magdalena

texts.es: María, a sus 57 años de edad, es casada y madre de tres hijos. Desde hace más de 30 años aprendió el oficio de la confección en un curso de capacitación que realizó y luego inició su propio negocio donde prestaba el servicio de modistería a diferentes personas del sector donde residía. Desde 1990, luego de haber ampliado sus conocimientos de y haber mejorado sus técnicas ella comenzó a confeccionar para terceros y, actualmente su mayor cliente es una reconocida tienda de deportes de la ciudad. Su taller está ubicado en su casa, allí está muy bien estructurado y a la vez puede alternar su trabajo con las labores del hogar. La cliente es una mujer dedicada, luchadora y muy organizada, con el apoyo de 7 créditos anteriores ha logrado fortalecer su negocio, por esta razón se motiva a solicitar un crédito más para comprar insumos al por mayor (lona y espuma) con lo que podrá sacar una gran producción que tiene pendiente y podrá mejorar sus ventas, atrayendo más clientes, lo que se reflejará en mejores ingresos para solventar las necesidades básicas de su hogar. María desea seguir trabajando arduamente para que en un futuro su negocio le permita sacar una línea propia de artículos y uniformes deportivos, y que le permita disfrutar de una mejor calidad de vida al lado de las personas que ama.
texts.en:
María, 57, is married and has three children.  Over 30 years ago she took a sewing course and then decided to open her own business offering sewing services to people in her neighborhood.  In 1990, after having increased her knowledge and improved her techniques she began working for third parties so now her best client is a well-known sportswear store in the city.  She works from home, which is well equipped, so she can alternate her work with the household activities.

The borrower is a delicate, hard-working, organized woman who has used her seven previous loans to strengthen her business.  She is motivated to request another loan to buy wholesale supplies (canvas and styrofoam) so she can produce pending orders.  This will increase her sales and attract more clients, giving her more income for household necessities.

María wants to continue working hard so that in the future she can launch her own line of sports uniforms and accessories.  This will give her and the people she loves a better lifestyle.

loans.use: To buy wholesale supplies (canvas and styrofoam)

loans.name: José Fernando

texts.es: José es un joven dinámico y emprendedor, que a sus 21 años de edad se dedica a atender su propio negocio, una tienda de abarrotes que adquirió hace un año, cuando los padres de un amigo eran propietarios de este negocio y pusieron la casa en arriendo porque se iban del país, por lo que José convenció a sus padres para tomar esta casa y así él podría continuar con la tienda, de esta forma ha logrado generar los recursos suficientes para aportar a la economía de su hogar y para pagar sus estudios universitarios. Trabaja muy juicioso todos los días de la semana desde las 8:00 am hasta las 9:30 pm, pero en los horarios que tiene clases, su madre o su hermano menor le colaboran atendiendo a los clientes. Él ve en esta actividad una gran fuente de ingresos y un negocio muy rentable, pues es consciente de que los productos de la canasta familiar se venden a diario. Actualmente solicita el apoyo del crédito para realizar mejoras locativas (arreglar carpa exterior y una banca) y para comprar surtido al por mayor (mecato, lácteos, huevos, granos, galletería, productos de aseo, entre otros), de esta forma su negocio tendrá una mejor imagen y además podrá abastecerse de productos de diferentes marcas para satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes, mejorando notablemente sus ventas y los ingresos que recibe de ellas. José con su espíritu de superación, desea seguir trabajando arduamente para sacar adelante su negocio, fortalecerlo y hacerlo crecer hasta convertirlo en un minimercado, que sea más rentable y que le permita ejercer sus profesión en su negocio; de esta manera desea mejorar la calidad de vida de la familia y terminar sus estudios universitarios.
texts.en:
José, 21, is a dynamic young entrepreneur who has his own business, a grocery store, which he started a year ago.  His parents were friends of the owners who rented out the property because they were leaving the country.  José convinced his parents to rent the house so he could set up a store and earn enough income to support the household economy and pay for university studies.  He works every day from 8:00 a.m. to 9:30 p.m.  During class time his mother or younger brother help at the store attending to customers.  

José believes this business is a good source of income and very profitable because families need to buy things on a daily basis.  He is requesting a loan to improve the store (fixing the outdoor awning and a bench) and to buy wholesale merchandise (cakes, dairy products, eggs, grains, cookies, personal hygiene products, etc.).  This will give his business a better image and allow him to have on hand different brands of products to satisfy customer demand.   Sales and income will improve considerably.  

José's determination to get ahead and continue working hard to strengthen his business and make it grow will allow him to turn it into a profitable mini-market where he can use his professsional knowledge.  He wants to improve his family's lifestyle and finish his university degree.

loans.use: To make store improvements (fix outdoor awning and a bench) and to buy goods wholesale (cakes, dairy products, eggs, grains, cookies, personal hygiene products, etc.)

loans.name: Larisa

texts.ru: Лариса разведена. Живет сама. Она торгует на рынке овощами и фруктами. Вот уже много лет, как ее квартира требует ремонта. Необходимо заменить старый туалет, трубы в ванной комнате, отремонтировать нагреватель для горячей воды, а также положить кафель в ваной комнате. Для всего этого Ларисе нужны средства в размере 5,000 гривен. Лариса обращается с просьбой помочь отремонтировать свою квартиру и улучшить жилищные условия.
texts.en: Larisa is divorced. She lives alone. She sells vegetables and fruit at the market. Her apartment has been in need of repair for many years now. It is necessary to replace her old toilet and the pipes in her washroom. She also needs to repair her hot water heater and lay tiling in the bathroom. For these repairs, Larisa needs 5,000 hryvnia. Larisa is making a request to help her repair her apartment and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to improve her living conditions.

loans.name: Galina

texts.ru:
Галина - вдова. У нее есть трое взрослых детей. Галина торгует детской и подростковой одеждой на рынке. В этом году Галина попала в больницу - были проблемы с желчным пузырем. Несмотря на трудности со здоровьем, она смогла преодолеть их и опять выйти на рынок торговать. Бизнес Галины - единственный источник ее дохода.

С целью привлечение большего числа покупателей Галине нужно расширить свой ассортимент. Галина хочет закупить теплые кофты и джинсы. Осень - время покупки теплой одежды и Галина надеется, что сможет увеличить товарооборот и соответственно свою прибыль.

Галина просит предоставить ей кредит в размере 5,000 гривен на закупку товара.
texts.en:
Galina is a widow. She has three grown-up children. Galina sells clothes for children and teenagers at the market. This year, Galina was in the hospital with gall-bladder problems. Despite the problems with her health, she was able to overcome them and start selling on the market again. Galina's business is her only source of income.

To attract more customers, Galina needs to expand her selection of clothes. Galina wants to buy warm jackets and jeans. Autumn is the time of year to buy warm clothes and Galina hopes that she can increase her sales turnover and thus, her profit. 

Galina is requesting a loan in the amount of 5,000 hryvnia to buy products for retail.

loans.use: to purchase jeans and jackets for retail sale.

loans.name: Jeanne Ablawa's Group

texts.fr: Ce groupe est composé de deux personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, nommée Jeanne Ablawa (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 46 ans. Jeanne Ablawa a très peu fréquenté l'école. Jeanne Ablawa est mariée à un certain Christophe. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Jeanne Ablawa et son mari assurent ensemble les diverses charges de la maison. C'est pour cette raison que dame, Jeanne Ablawa vend depuis quinze ans des tissus, des glacières, des chaussures et des bijoux par la méthode de distribution. Jeanne Ablawa s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité, Jeanne Ablawa s’associe aux autres membres de son groupe pour solliciter un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en: This group is made up of two people who live in the same neighbourhood.  The group representative is Jeanne Ablawa (with her hand raised in the photo), who is 46 years old.  Jeanne Ablawa did not attend much school.  She is married to Christophe, and they have two children who are their financial responsibility, and who both attend school.  Jeanne Ablawa and Christophe are responsible for all the expenses of their household.  This is why she has distributed fabric, coolers, shoes and jewellery for 15 years.  She buys her supplies at a market in Benin.  In order to strengthen her business, Jeanne Ablawa has joined with the other member of her group to request this first loan from the field partner Alidé.

loans.use: to buy fabric, coolers, shoes and jewellery.

loans.name: Anna

texts.ru:
Анна – молодой предприниматель из Запорожья. Она торгует на одном из самых крупных рынков города – Анголенко. Она торгует польскими детскими товарами: верхней одеждой, бельем, шапочками и конвертами. Этот товар Анна считает самым качественным из доступных по цене большинству населения города. 

В этом году Анна нашла производителей своего товара в Польше и теперь работает с ними напрямую. Благодаря КИВА кредитам, Анна может передавать деньги поставщикам авансом (электронным платежем) и получать товар по более низкой цене. На данный момент кредит в 5,000 гривен Анне необходим для закупки зимних детских шапок.
texts.en:
Anna is a young entrepreneur from Zaporozhye. She sells goods at Angolenko market, one of the biggest markets in the city. She sells Polish children's products: outerwear, underwear, hats and jackets. Anna considers her products to be the highest quality goods which are affordable to the residents of the city.

This year, Anna found the manufacturer of her products in Poland and now she works with them directly. Thanks to Kiva loans, Anna can transfer money to her suppliers as an advance (through electronic payments) and receive her products at a lower price. Anna currently needs 5,000 hryvnia to buy warm children's hats for winter.

loans.use: to purchase children's hats for retail sale.

loans.name: Cyntha

texts.en: Cynthia, age 48, is a university graduate. She lives in the community of Congo Town called Chugbor. She is a widow and the mother of two children who are ages 10 and 16, and who are currently in school. Cynthia started her business with the initial capital of 8,000 LRD, which she received from her brother. She has sold salt, pepper, onion, palm oil, vita, rice and black pepper for the past 15 years. She likes this type of business because she makes a profit. With the profit she buys more goods and attends to the needs of her children. Cynthia is requesting her fourth loan to purchase more rice, vita, onion, pepper and cooking oil for the business. Her plan is to become an international businesswoman.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, vita, onion, pepper and cooking oil for the business.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is 29 years old and lives in the West Point community, which is a populated area in Montserrado County. She is living together with her spouse and 2-year-old child. She stopped her education in the seventh grade but she sells pig feet through a business she manages well. Beatrice has sold these goods for the past eight years without encountering any problems. Her mother assisted with some funds, which she used to start her business. Beatrice is asking for a loan to buy more pig feet for her business in order to have some sustainable future plan.

loans.use: to buy more pig feet for her business.

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.ru:
Татьяна - предприниматель из Запорожья. Она продает женскую обувь. Благодаря предыдущему КИВА кредиту Татьяна увеличила товарооборот и получила дополнительную прибыль. 

Татьяна - вдова, живет вместе с сыном. В этом году они продали часть дома, где они жили и переехали в квартиру. За квартирой нужно меньше ухода, чем за домом, поэтому Татьяне теперь легче и остатется больше времени для бизнеса и для сына.

Татьяна участвовала в обувной выставке со своим товаром. Это помогло ей увидеть современные тренды и принимать правильные решения при закупке обуви. Татьяна просит предоставить ей кредит в размере 21,000 гривен для покупки женской зимней обуви. Она надеется получить дополнительную прибыль и продолжать помогать сыну оплачивать колледж, где он учится.
texts.en:
Tatyana is an entrepreneur from Zaporozhye. She sells women's shoes. Thanks to her previous Kiva loan, Tatyana increased her sales turnover and received additional profits.

Tatyana is a widow who lives with her son. This year, they sold the part of their house where they lived and moved into an apartment. An apartment requires less upkeep than a house, so its now easier for Tatyana and she has more time for her business and her son. 

Tatyana took part in a shoe exposition with her products. This helped her to find out the latest trends and make correct decisions when purchasing shoes. Tatyana is asking for a loan in the amount of 21,000 hryvnia to buy women's winter shoes. She hopes to receive additional profits and continue to help her son pay for college, where he is currently studying.

loans.use: to purchase women's winter shoes for retail sale.

loans.name: Miguel Antonio

texts.es: Miguel, con 46 años de edad, es padre soltero de un hijo adolescente y cabeza de hogar. Por dificultades económicas y por falta de oportunidades laborales, decidió iniciar su propio negocio y comenzó a vender frutas en una carreta, se ubica a las afueras de una de las estaciones del tren de la ciudad y de esta forma ha logrado generar los recursos suficientes para sacar a su hijo adelante y para solventar las necesidades básicas de su hogar. Su empuje, empeño y dedicación le han permitido salir adelante, sobrepasando diversos obstáculos, especialmente económicos, sin embargo esto no lo detiene para seguir luchando y lograr sus objetivos. Actualmente solicita el crédito para invertirlo en el pago del saldo de un crédito que tiene vigente y para comprar surtido al por mayor (frutas en cosecha), de esta forma podrá disminuir costos y así mejorar el margen de ganancias que obtiene por las ventas de estas frutas. Miguel sueña con seguir trabajando arduamente y ahorrar para que en un futuro cercano pueda montar otro puesto de venta de frutas y así poder brindar oportunidad de empleo a un familiar, así mejorará no sólo su calidad de vida, sino también la de su núcleo familiar, además tendrá la posibilidad de dar a su hijo una mejor educación.
texts.en: Miguel is 46 years old. He is a single father of a teenage son and a head of household. Due to financial difficulties and a lack of work opportunities, he decided to start his own business and began to sell fruit from a cart. It is located outside of one of the city train stations and this generated enough income    to get his son ahead and pay for the basic household expenses. His drive, hard work and dedication have allowed him to get ahead, overcoming different obstacles, especially financial ones. They haven't stopped him from continuing to fight to achieve his goals. Right now, he is asking for the loan to invest in paying off an existing loan that he has and to buy merchandise wholesale (fruit in season). This way, he can lower costs and improve his profit margin from selling the fruit. Miguel dreams of continuing to work hard and save so that in the near future he can open another fruit sales locale an offer a job opportunity to a relative. This way, not only will he improve his own quality of life, but that of his family as well. He will also have the possibility of giving his son a better education.

loans.use: to pay off an existing loan that he has and to buy merchandise wholesale (fruit in season).

loans.name: Jorge Humberto

texts.es: Jorge, a sus 37 años de edad, es casado y padre de tres hijos. Durante 15 años se ha dedicado a trabajar como maestro de obras de construcción, prestando sus servicios en diferentes municipios de la región antioqueña. Esta actividad la aprendió de su familia y ha sido su principal fuente de ingresos con los que ha podido sacar adelante a sus hijos y esposa. Se caracteriza por ser un hombre trabajador, pujante y activo, sus ganas de progresar lo impulsan a buscar opciones para seguir avanzando, por ello solicita el crédito, con el que comprará activos y herramientas de trabajo (máquina cortadora, pulidora, motosierra y herramientas de mano), con lo que podrá mejorar sus trabajos y atraer nuevos clientes, además podrá disminuir los costos de producción, pues tendrá la maquinaria necesaria para realizar las labores y no tendrá que recurrir al alquiler de equipos y herramientas. Todo esto se verá reflejado en el incremento de sus ingresos, con los que podrá brindar un mejor bienestar a su familia y disfrutar de mejores condiciones de vida en compañía de sus hijos y su esposa.
texts.en:
37-year-old Jorge is married and has three children. He has worked for fifteen years as a foreman in different construction sites around the region of Antioquia. He learned this activity from his family and it has been his main source of income, helping him to support his children and wife.

Jorge is known to be a hardworking, persistent and energetic man. His will to get ahead makes him look for more opportunities to progress and this is why he is requesting a loan. He will buy tools (a cutting machine, a sanding machine, a chain saw and manual tools) that will help him to improve the quality of his works and attract new clients. He will also reduce his costs, since he will have the machines he requires without needing to rent them from someone else. All this will result in an increase in his income, well-being for his family and the possibility to enjoy better living conditions together with his wife and children.

loans.use: to buy tools such as a cutting machine, a sanding machine, a chainsaw and manual tools.

loans.name: Nancy's Group

texts.en:
Nancy is 36 years old and has 4 children - 3 daughters aged 7, 11, and 3, and a son aged 4. She lives in Jemaga village in Galona, Kenya. Jemaga village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from an unprotected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Nancy and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Nancy works as a peasant farmer, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Nancy and other promoters in her community - Everlyne, Paulo and Solomon, need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Nancy will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. She wants to be a promoter because she believes the program will help prevent waterborne diseases. Nancy believes that the dispenser will help her community prevent sickness and access safe water.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits.  Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Nancy’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Tenneh

texts.en: Tanneh is a 36-year-old woman and lives at the West point area which has the most populated market in the Montserrado County. She is married, and has 3 children aged between 10 and 15 years.  Only one is  in school and two of her children live at home. She described herself as a hardworking woman.  For the past three years she has been running a market-table where she sells rice, oil, pepper, onion etc in the local market.  She sells six days a week from 7am to 6pm.  She likes her business because of the ways customers buy from her, and she started this business with money given to her by husband. She used a shard-taxi every time to get her goods at her business spot. She is requesting a loan to purchase more rice, oil, pepper, onion etc for her business, she plans is to build a house for her children.  She likes to say thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase more rice, oil, pepper, onion etc for her business,

loans.name: Finda

texts.en: Finda is 32 years old and lives in the West point area which has the most populated market in the Montserrado County. She is single and was unable to go to school. She described herself as a hardworking woman. For the past four years, she has been selling soft drinks in the local market. She sells six days a week from 7am to 5pm. She likes her business because of the ways customers buy from her.  She started this business with money given to her by mother.  She uses a shared-taxi every time to get her goods to her business spot.  She is requesting a loan to purchase more soft drinks for her business. She plans to build a house for her children. She likes to say thanks to the lenders who support BRAC Liberia.

loans.use: to purchase more soft drinks for her business.

loans.name: Florence's Group

texts.en:
Florence of Museywa village in Jipchekwen, Kenya, has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. 42 year old Florence has some primary school education. She lives in house with mud walls, a dirt floor, and an iron roof with her husband and 7 children. 

Museywa village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink.

Florence and the 14 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining a chlorine dispenser at the water sources. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Jimin, Damaris, Phanice and Mary. 

Florence has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. She volunteered to be the promoter because she is well-liked and is reliable. She believes the chlorine dispenser will ensure the community has good health.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Florence’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To install and maintain chlorine dispensers to provide access to safe drinking water for the community.

loans.name: Gladys' Group

texts.en:
Gladys is 57 years old and has 3 children. She lives in Gimarakwa B village in Kenya. Gimarakwa B village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a protected dug well. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Gladys and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Gladys is a retired nurse, and is involved in farming activities. She has volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Gladys and other promoters in her community - Ali, Cliffe and Catherine need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Gladys will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. She wants to be a promoter because she has been a nurse and has also been volunteering to help people. She wants to help to encourage people to continuously use chlorine because of her knowledge in health matters. Gladys believes that the chlorine in the dispenser will kill germs to make water safe for community to use.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Gladys’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To support an innovative water treatment technology - chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Ruth's Group

texts.en:
In Kitambazi A village in Gimarakwa, Kenya, Ruth has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Ruth is a well-liked member of the community with 6 children who are 18, 15, 12, 10, 8 and 5 years old. Ruth name lives in a house with mud walls, a dirt floor, and an iron roof with her husband and children.

Kitambazi A village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a river. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Ruth and the 30 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Two other promoters from the neighboring villages, Eric and Joseph, are part of this group loan.  

Ruth has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. She volunteered to be the promoter because she saw the need to support the community. She believes the dispenser will reduce waterborne diseases thus enhance a healthy life. 

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Ruth’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To reduce the burden of water-borne diseases by providing access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers.

loans.name: Benjamin's Group

texts.en:
In Kipsigor village in Givogi, Kenya, Benjamin  has volunteered to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser. Benjamin has 5 children, and is a friendly, goal oriented, hardworking, reliable and trustworthy, well liked member of the community. Benjamin lives in a house with mud walls, a dirt floor, and an iron roof with his wife and children. 

Kipsigor village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a river. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. Chlorine dispensers offer a solution to this problem by allowing people to treat their water to make it safe to drink. Benjamin and the 10 other households using the local water source need a loan to cover the cost of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. 

Benjamin has volunteered to act as the promoter to encourage the community to use the dispenser and to refill it with chlorine when the tank runs low. He volunteered to be the promoter because he values health and wants to help the community be healthy. He believes the dispenser will help kill bacteria and prevent diseases. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Lucy, Francis, Hezron and Jane.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Benjamin’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.use: To ensure that the community has access to safe drinking water via chlorine dispensers

loans.name: Catherine's Group

texts.en:

The community of Chepturei village collects their drinking water from a protected spring because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Chepturei’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source, where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans, then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from re-contamination. In Chepturei, 25 households will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water.

Catherine has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy. Catherine volunteered to be the promoter because she believes that the dispenser will prevent waterborne diseases. Chepturei village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Isack,Phanice, Risper and Shem.   

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Catherine’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. loans.name: Gulguncha

texts.ru: Гулгунча родилась в 1970 года. Она замужем и воспитывает 4 детей. Она хранительница очага своего дома. Гулгунча всегда хотела, чтобы ее дети получили высшее образование и стали высококвалифицированными специалистами. Она работает в государственном учреждении. Гулгунча полученную зарплату старается тратить целенаправленно и без лишних затрат, но ее зарплата маленькая и не хватает для оплаты учебного договора своих детей, которые учатся в школе и в университете. Ее старший ребенок учится в Национальном Университете Таджикистана, и она должна оплатить за учебный договор. Она запрашивает займ на сумму 4700 сомони. Она ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en: Gulguncha was born in 1970. She is married and is raising 4 children. She is a homemaker and manages the household. Gulguncha always wanted her children to receive a higher education and become highly qualified specialists. She works in a government agency. Gulguncha does her best to spend her salary purposefully and without wasteful spending, but her salary is small and not enough to pay for the children's tuitions, who study at school and at university. Her oldest child studies at the National University of Tajikistan and she needs to pay for his tuition. She is requesting a loan in the amount of 4,700 somoni. She awaits your kindness.

loans.use: To pay for education of her child at the university

loans.name: Resitala

texts.en: Resitala is a 27-year-old lady with one child. She wants to start a small business making and selling pancakes in her community. To do this, she needs a loan to buy flour, sugar, yeast, dripping oil and plastic bags. In the future, Resitala hopes to improve her business, upgrade her family standards of living and help her child's education. She joined SPBD in 2013 to gain access to financial services.

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar, yeast, dripping oil and plastic bags.

loans.name: Meleane

texts.en: Meleane is a 66-year-old widow with 4 children. She makes and sells pancakes, rice and curry in Vailuutai Primary School and in her community to earn a living. She has 2 years of experience with this business. Meleane needs a loan to buy flour, sugar, dripping oil, baking soda, boxes of chicken, bags of rice, curry powder and a kerosene oven. She plans to use her profits to save for family needs. Meleane has been a member of SPBD since 2013.

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar, dripping oil, baking soda, boxes of chicken, bags of rice, curry powder and a kerosene oven.

loans.name: Mary's Group

texts.en:
Mary is 65 years old and has 7 children, and she lives in Kavoi A village in Kalwani, Kenya. She is friendly, hardworking, reliable, trustworthy, well known, and well liked. Kavoi A village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from a river. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Mary and her family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Mary works as a subsistence farmer growing food crops, but has also volunteered her time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables her community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Mary and other promoters (including: Joyce, Gladys, Benson, and Lucy) in her community need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Mary will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. Mary wants to be a promoter because she is readily available and willing to serve the community. Mary believes that the dispenser will provide chlorine which helps to prevent illnesses like diarrhea and other waterborne diseases.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Mary’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.name: William

texts.es: William es un hombre de 41 años de edad, padre de cuatro hijos y vive en unión libre con su compañera sentimental. Durante 13 años se ha dedicado a trabajar en su propio negocio, una venta de crispetas, sus ventas las realiza en una moto que adecuó para llevar su producto por uno de los corregimientos de la ciudad; de esta forma ha podido generar los recursos necesarios para llevar el sustento diario a su hogar. El cliente es un hombre pujante y activo, se esmera por sacar adelante a sus hijos y su esposa y, siempre busca opciones que le permitan seguir avanzando. Solicita el crédito para invertirlo en los arreglos del vehículo donde vende sus productos (cambiar llantas y arreglar motor), de esta forma mejorará las condiciones de trabajo y podrá continuar con su labor, generando los recursos que requiere para sostener a su familia y con los que podrá ahorrar para en un futuro poder adquirir una casa propia, donde pueda disfrutar de mejores condiciones de vida y bienestar al lado de las personas que ama.
texts.en: William is a 41 year old man and the father of four children and lives with his partner. For 13 years he has worked at his own business selling popcorn. He sells from a motorcycle that he adapted to take his product through city neighborhoods. In this way, he has been able to generate enough resources to support his home. He is a driven and active man who works hard to get his children and wife ahead. He is always seeking opportunities that will allow him to keep advancing. He is asking for the loan to invest in repairing the vehicle he sells his products from (changing the tires and fixing the motor). In this way, he will improve his work conditions and be able to continue with his work, generating resources he needs to support his family and save so that in the future he can acquire his own home and enjoy a better quality of life and well being for the ones he loves.

loans.use: to pay for repairs on the vehicle where he sells his products (to change the tires and fix the motor).

This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause water-borne diseases. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Fred’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Samson, Rodah, Margret, and Roselynne.

Kegondi village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Judith believes that the dispenser will allow the community to use safe water which will reduce risk of waterborne diseases and therefore the community will have better health conditions. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Judith’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.name: Everline's Group

texts.en:
Everline lives in a home with concrete walls, a concrete floor, and an iron roof in Vojo village in Gasianga, Kenya with her family. She is a subsistence farmer and is actively involved in the women's group in her community. The community of Vojo village collects their drinking water from a river because there is no piped water supply in this part of rural Kenya. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, often making Vojo’s inhabitants sick and unable to work or attend school.

A new chlorine dispenser offers a solution to the burden of sickness caused by unsafe drinking water. The dispenser is installed at the local water source, where users turn a valve to add chlorine to their jerricans, then collect water as usual. The chlorine disinfects the water and provides residual protection from recontamination. In Vojo, 13 households will benefit from having access to the dispenser and safe water.  Everline has volunteered to be the dispenser promoter, who is responsible for refilling the chlorine and encouraging the rest of the community to treat their water and keep themselves and their families healthy.  There are four other volunteer promoters from the surrounding community who are part of this group loan: Elias, Violet, Benson, and Hariet.

Vojo village needs a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining the dispenser. Everline believes that the dispenser will provide safe water which prevents diseases affecting her community. The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. The sale of carbon credits, to organizations and individuals wanting to reduce their carbon footprint, will be used to repay Kiva lenders and also to make sure that Everline’s community can have access to safe water now and in the future.

loans.name: Vincent's Group

Vincent is 29 years old and lives in Erusui A village in Serem, Kenya. Vincent is known for being friendly, hardworking, reliable, and well-liked. In his community, Vincent is active in the prayer group and the burial committee. Erusui A village does not have a piped water supply, so the community collects their water from an unprotected spring. This water is easily contaminated with bacteria that can cause diarrhea and other water-borne diseases, meaning that Vincent and his family may fall sick and become unable to work or attend school.

Vincent works as a commercial farmer, but has also volunteered his time to be the promoter for a new chlorine dispenser program that enables his community to drink safe water and stay healthy. Vincent and other promoters in his community including Fred, Violet, Phanice, and Anne need a loan to cover the costs of installing and maintaining chlorine dispensers at the water sources in the area. Vincent will encourage the community to treat their water with the dispenser, and refill the dispenser with chlorine as needed. He wants to be a promoter because he loves his community and now that they have received this important gadget for water treatment, he believes it is important to take advantage of the opportunity. Vincent believes that the dispenser provides safe water and improves their health making them less sick. This also means they will spend less money going to the hospital. Additionally, healthier lives will enable them to do their work properly and earn a living.

The Kiva loan will be repaid by Evidence Action (www.evidenceaction.org) on behalf of the community, through the sale of carbon credits. Using the chlorine dispenser generates carbon credits by avoiding the need to boil water to make it safe to drink. loans.name: James

texts.en:
James lives close to Cherengani, near Kitale town. Kitale is located in the Trans-Nzoia district of western Kenya, and at over 6,300 feet above sea level, is one of Africa’s most elevated towns. The rich soil of the area makes it one of the nation's biggest maize producing regions, lending it the nickname of “the breadbasket of Kenya.” Many farmers in the region have started projects planting bluegum trees on their land, which complement the region’s natural forests and provide bees with a variety of food sources. The people around Kitale have been beekeeping for centuries, and the area is dense with strong bee colonies.  

James works as a farmer, and is cultivating maize and beans on his farm. He has been farming for 10 years. He is married, and has four children. James is very excited about becoming a beekeeper, as he believes it is a good project with good returns.

James plans on using the income generated by his beehives to educate his children.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Elisha

texts.en:
Elisha lives on a farm outside of Kitale town, in Kitale county. Kitale is located in the Trans-Nzoia district of western Kenya. It is located close to Uganda, and Mount Elgon, an extinct volcano which straddles the two nations and even has a peak at the Kenya-Uganda border. Founded by European settlers in the early 1900s, Kitale originally grew due to its proximity to the Ugandan railway. The area around Kitale is filled with natural forests, and maintenance of tree cover by the area’s residents has helped preserve the region’s soil and ensured that the area remains good for beekeeping. Kitale is the headquarters of the Kenya Seed Company, whose massive sunflower plantations provide nearby bees with a veritable buffet of high-quality forage. 

Elisha is married, and has six children. His wife works as a teacher, while he farms their land. He has been farming for over 18 years, and cultivates maize, beans, vegetables, and bananas, and he has many trees on his farm. 

Eilsha sees Honey Care’s partnership with Kiva as a great way to start beekeeping, which he believes is a business that will enable him to educate his children. Elisha is one of the founding members of the community based organization that many individuals in his region have joined, and his hope for the future is to continue to find projects and programs that will benefit the members and achieve the objectives of his group.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David lives and works in the Cherengani region, close to Kitale town. Kitale is located in the Trans-Nzoia district of western Kenya. Originally dominated by English settlers in the early 20th century, the region’s farmland was redistributed after independence. This left Trans-Nzoia as one of Kenya’s most cosmopolitan areas, with individuals from a variety of linguistic and ethnic groups living in close proximity. The lush soil of the region ensures that farmers can grow a variety of crops, including maize, sunflower, sugar cane, millet, and beans. Kitale is located near Mount Elgon, East Africa's oldest and largest solitary extinct volcano, whose substantial forest cover makes Kitale a high-potential beekeeping region. 

David is married, and has seven children. Both he and his wife farm their land, and he has been farming for 20 years. He is currently growing maize, beans and horticulture products, as well as practicing dairy farming. 

David is very excited about starting to become a beekeeper: he describes himself as “a happy man” because now the trees on his farm will benefit him by helping aid in the production of honey. 

David’s hope for the future is to continue with beekeeping and expand his farming activities.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Anne

texts.en:
Anne lives in the Cherengani region, close to Kitale town. Kitale is located in the Trans-Nzoia district of western Kenya, and at over 6,300 feet above sea level, is one of Africa’s most elevated towns. The rich soil of the area makes it one of the nation's biggest maize producing regions, lending it the nickname of “the breadbasket of Kenya.” Many farmers in the region have started projects planting bluegum trees on their land, which complement the region’s natural forests and provide bees with a variety of food sources. The people around Kitale have been beekeeping for centuries, and the area is dense with strong bee colonies.  

Anne is married, and has seven children. Both she and her husband are farmers; they plant maize, beans, and bananas and practice dairy farming. They have done this for a period of 15 years. Anne is excited to become a beekeeper, as this will help her achieve the objectives of the community group she has joined. 

Anne’s hope for the future is to diversity her revenue stream from her farm. She says farmers in the area have over-relied on maize and in the past three years production of maize has not been so good due to drastically changing weather as well as fungal diseases that are destroying their maize crop entirely. Bee keeping will be an alternative source of income for her and the entire community, and will help provide for their needs.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:

Originally dominated by English settlers in the early 20th century, the region’s farmland was redistributed after independence. This left Trans-Nzoia one of Kenya’s most cosmopolitan areas, with individuals from a variety of linguistic and ethnic groups living in close proximity. 

The lush soil of the region ensures that farmers can grow a variety of crops, including maize, sunflower, sugar cane, millet, and beans. Kitale is located near Mount Elgon, East Africa's oldest and largest solitary extinct volcano, whose substantial forest cover makes Kitale a high-potential beekeeping region. 

Alice is married, and she has five children. She teaches young children, while her husband works as a social service officer. Alice also farms her land: she cultivates maize, vegetables, beans, and bananas, and she has an orchard with various fruit plants. She also does livestock rearing.

Alice is happy that she will get hives for the production of honey, as she loves honey and hopes to enjoy the income as well.

This is Alice’s first loan, and she plans to use much of this money coming from the sale of honey for her children’s education.

She thanks Kiva lenders for this initiative.  She believes that it will reduce the level of poverty in her area.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas is married, and has three children. She works as a teacher, while her husband is in the agriculture sector. When asked about why she is interested in beekeeping, Dorcas said that she can’t express her happiness at being part of honey production. She originally came from Marakwet, a region in the northeast part of Kenya, before her family was settled near Kitale, and when she was younger her neighbors did bee keeping. Dorcas “can’t forget those days as a young girl enjoying honey.” Although she was the last member of her group to show up to the meeting, and had to walk a long distance to register for this program, she remained enthusiastic, and said that she “lacks adjectives to describe her happiness and gratitude to KIVA.”

Dorcas lives in the Cherengani region, near Kitale town. Kitale is located in the Trans-Nzoia district of western Kenya. It is located close to Uganda and Mount Elgon, an extinct volcano which straddles the two nations and even has a peak at the Kenya-Uganda border. Founded by European settlers in the early 1900's, Kitale originally grew due to its proximity to the Ugandan railway. The area around Kitale is filled with natural forests, and maintenance of tree cover by the area’s residents has helped both preserve the region’s soil and ensured that the area remains good for beekeeping. Kitale is the headquarters of the Kenya Seed Company, whose massive sunflower plantations provide nearby bees with a veritable buffet of high-quality forage.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John lives and works in the Cherengani area, outside of the town of Kitale. Kitale is located in the Trans-Nzoia district of Western Kenya, and is over 6,300 feet above sea level; it is one of Africa’s most elevated towns. The rich soil of the area makes it one of the nation's biggest maize producing regions, lending it the nickname of “the breadbasket of Kenya.” Many farmers in the region have started projects planting blue-gum trees on their land, which complement the region’s natural forests and provide bees with a variety of food sources. The people around Kitale have been beekeeping for centuries, and the area is dense with strong bee colonies.  

John is married, and has five children. He works as a farmer as well as a pastor; his wife focuses on farming. They have been farming for 10 years and plant maize, beans, and orchards growing guava, avocado, and mangoes. 

John is excited about Honey Care’s projects because he thinks that beekeeping will bring unity in his area. He says that the area in which he lives is a hot spot during political boiling points due to the area's demographics. His hope for the future is “to tackle poverty and tribalism through beekeeping and I can’t say enough thank you to our benefactors.’’

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production for his agriculture business.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:

The area around Kitale is filled with natural forests, and the maintenance of tree covers by the area’s residents has helped both preserve the region’s soil and ensured that the area remains good for beekeeping. Kitale is the headquarters of the Kenya Seed Company, whose massive sunflower plantations provide nearby bees with a veritable buffet of high-quality forage. 

Peter is married and has four children. Both him and his wife have been farming for twenty three years and are currently growing maize, an orchard, beans, and bananas and rearing livestock. 

Peter is looking forward to becoming a beekeeper because the hives do not take up much space on his farm, yet still produce good income. 

This is Peter’s first loan with Kiva, and he plans to use the income from his hives to “improve farming in general.”

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Michael

The rich soil of the area makes it one of the nation's biggest maize producing regions lending it the nickname of “the breadbasket of Kenya”. Many farmers in the region have started projects planting Blue Gum trees on their land which complement the region’s natural forests and provide bees with a variety of food sources. The people around Kitale have been beekeeping for centuries, and the area is dense with strong bee colonies.  

Kilimo is married and has eight children. He has been farming for 42 years and is currently growing maize, cassava, millet and sorghum as well as tending to livestock. Kilimo is also currently beekeeping, and he is excited to expand the number of his hives as he knows that the honey business is profitable and has extra benefits for his farm such as pollination. 

This is Kilimo’s first loan with Kiva, and he plans to use the income from his hives: “to buy more land for my family and buy a cow. It will also be for my family's upkeep.”

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: David

Founded by European settlers in the early 1900s, Kitale originally grew due to its proximity to the Ugandan railway. The area around Kitale is filled with natural forests, and maintenance of tree cover by the area’s residents has helped both preserve the region’s soil and ensured that the area remains good for beekeeping. Kitale is the headquarters of the Kenya Seed Company, whose massive sunflower plantations provide nearby bees with a veritable buffet of high-quality forage. 

David is married and has four children. Both him and his wife are farmers and are currently growing maize, bananas and oranges on their land. David is looking forward to becoming a beekeeper because the bees will help pollinate his crops, especially his fruit. 

This is David’s first loan with Kiva, and he plans to use the income generated by his beehives to help educate his children.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Lynda

texts.en:
Lynda, who is originally from New York City, has lived in Boston since 1990.

She has been working on home remodeling and painting since 1997 as an individual contractor. Since May of 2005, Lynda is the founder and sole operator of Narman Construction Inc., a fully insured and licensed general contractor corporation which specializes in roofing, kitchen design, bathroom remodeling and painting, and other auxiliary services. Her business is accredited A+ by the Better Business Bureau.

Narman Construction Inc. was originally founded and owned by Lynda and her ex-husband in 2005, but once they separated and, eventually divorced, she became the sole owner and operator. Determined to not give up on her business and her entrepreneur goals, she has continued to expand and grow the business through tough economic times. "When I decided to embark on becoming one of very few general contractors in the state, I never dreamed there would be so many opportunities for women in the trade," she says. Despite various setbacks, Lynda has persevered.

One of the difficulties that Lynda has run into is securing working capital to cover labor, materials, and the needed equipment to complete jobs. Lynda’s success to date derives from her outstanding customer service, as she provides estimates and consultations to better understand the needs of her potential clients and, of course, timely and accurate completion of the projects. Her clients include homeowners, commercial property managers, and some projects from the state of MA.

Help Lynda continue to build her dream with a loan.

loans.use: to obtain Xactimate training and continuing education as required by the state.

loans.name: Rubi

texts.en:
Rubi, who hails from the Dominican Republic, started Total Green Cleaning two and a half years ago. His business offers a wide variety of services to numerous clients in the Central Florida region, from corporate establishments to residential homes. 

Rubi lives at home with his daughter and hopes to continue building his business in order to someday pass it on to her. One of the most challenging aspects of owning his own business is not having the necessary cash flow. Rubi says, "It's hard when I don't have the money upfront to pay my employees. Finding a loan has been close to impossible... all I want is to establish a stable business."

Total Green Cleaning is committed to the environment and all products used are eco-friendly. One of the most requested services is carpet cleaning; this service includes pre-spray application, deep steam cleaning and carpet deodorizer. Rubi also does painting, remodeling and renovation, drywall repair, flooring installation, new bathrooms/kitchens, and general renovations. 

Rubi needs additional working capital to buy a new computer and an updated version of QuickBooks. Help him achieve his dreams with a loan!

loans.use: To purchase a new computer and an updated version of Quickbooks.

loans.name: Delton

texts.en:
“If you build it, they will come.” This was the quote which inspired Delton to start his own auto detailing and cleaning business. Delton watched others and learned from their example how to run his business.  Little by little, his determination to get the job done and his ability to connect with his customers built him a steady base of clients.

Since the early 90s, Delton has woken up early every morning, ended later than scheduled, and worked on the weekends in order to make sure that he provides the most convenient service to his clientele. He has also shifted his business to focus on the use of green products that protect the paint coat on the vehicles he services.  His hard work has paid off--Delton has become very well known in the community for providing quality service.

Now, Delton has reached a point where he needs to hire additional help to ensure the quality of customer service with which he built the foundation of his business. With this loan, Delton will hire an employee to keep up with the demand. Delton is excited to be able to share with this employee his own experience and teach them about being a business owner. 

Help Delton hire an additional employee for his business, ensuring the future of his business!

loans.use: To expand his business by hiring an independent contractor.

loans.name: Iliui

texts.en: Iliui is a 54-year-old married woman with 12 children. She makes and sells curry and rice in her community to earn a living. She has three years of experience with this business. Iliui needs a loan to buy a bag of rice, boxes of chicken, salt, garlic, onions, flour and cooking oil. She plans to use her profits to improve her business and help her family financially.

loans.use: to buy a bag of rice, boxes of chicken, salt, garlic, onions, flour and cooking oil

loans.name: Naimah

texts.en:
In 1982, Naimah was a homeless single mother with three children and one skill--she could type. It was shortly thereafter that Naimah discovered that two of her children had learning disabilities. In an effort to help them, she spent two summers in New York City learning the Spalding Reading method in order to teach her children how to read. She realized she had a knack for teaching and began teaching both children and adults how to read, meeting them in their homes and at local fast food establishments.

Through hard work and dedication, Naimah obtained an AS in Small Business Management and was pursuing a BA in General Business. However, Naimah endured another setback when she was diagnosed with carpal tunnel and fibromyalgia. "The doctor suggested I change my lifestyle, so I did. I quit a high-paying job at a utility company and started my life all over again," she says. It was after this setback that Naimah returned to teaching. She obtained her Masters in elementary curriculums, certificate in graduate studies in early childhood, and a Master's in adult learning. It was after this that she launched Babbling Brook Family Tutoring Services (BBFTS).

BBFTS will offer after-school programs as well as general services for those who want to improve their grammar and conversational skills. Clients will be students age 14 and up and the Spanish speaking population in the East Boston area, where the business is located. Lessons will be offered in group classes, as well as one on one consultation. Naimah has two partners in her business--a woman who speaks Spanish and a her youngest daughter who serves as her accountant and bookkeeper. 

Naimah is looking for capital to cover the lease for her learning center and to purchase advertising in order to promote her business.

Help Naimah help others with your loan.

loans.use: To cover the lease for her learning center and advertising to build a client base.

loans.name: Roziya

texts.ru: Розия добросовестная и трудолюбивая женщина. Ей 53 года. Розия с юных лет была жизнерадостной и позитивной женщиной. Она всегда мечтала стать любимой женой и хорошей мамой. Однако она не сошлась с мужем и после нескольких лет семейной жизни, она развелась. Розия воспитывает одного сына. Она не вышла замуж во второй раз и посвятила всю свою жизнь своему сыну. Розия работает в государственном учреждении. Она честно выполняет свою работу и поэтому ее начальство довольно ее работой. Скоро ее сын жениться. Розия хочет отремонтировать свой дом. Розия давно мечтала, чтобы ее сын женился, и она сыграла пышную свадьбу. Однако она вместе с сыном живёт в доме, которое имеет плохое состояние. Она срочно должна отремонтировать свой дом, но она не имеет денег, чтобы купить строительные материалы как цемент, краски, обои и т.п. Она ждет вашу доброту.
texts.en: Roziya is a conscientious and hardworking woman. She is 53 years old. From a young age, Roziya has been a cheerful and positive woman. She always dreamed of becoming a beloved wife and good mother. However, she did not get along with her husband and after several years of family life, she got divorced. Roziya is raising one son. She did not get remarried and has dedicated her whole life to her son. Roziya works in a state agency. She does her job honestly, which is why her boss is pleased with her work. Her son is getting married very soon. Roziya wants to repair her house. Roziya has long dreamed of her son getting married and giving him a spectacular wedding. However, she lives with her son at their house, which is in a state of disrepair. She urgently needs to repair her house, but she does not have the money to buy construction materials like cement, paint, wall-paper, etc. She awaits your kindness.

loans.use: To buy building materials such as cement, paint and wall-paper to repair her house.

loans.name: Fonofili

texts.en:
Fonofili is 44 years old and married with five children. She runs a small business selling chop suey, chicken curry, steamed rice and BBQ in her community and has been doing this for two years.

Fonifili has requested a loan to buy boxes of chicken, foil, a bag of rice, curry powder, garlic, onions, gas and foam plates. She joined SPBD in 2009 to gain access to capital. With her earnings, Fonofili will use her profits to improve her business and help her kids' education.

loans.use: to buy boxes of chicken, foil, a bag of rice, curry powder, garlic, onions, gas and foam plates

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Rosalina is 28 years old and married with one child. She owns and operates a business venture, Elei. She has two years of experience in this line of business. Rosalina needs a loan to buy a roll of materials, fabric,  colored paints, stencils, brushes and an 'elei' board design. She hopes to use her profits to provide for family daily needs. She joined SPBD in 2013.

loans.use: to buy a roll of materials, fabric,  colored paints, stencils, brushes and an 'elei' board design

loans.name: Faimeaalii

texts.en:
Faimeaalii is a 39-year-old married woman with two children. She has a small vegetable garden and grows cabbages. tomatoes, eggplant, etc to earn a living. She has been doing this for two years. Faimeaalii has requested a loan to buy fertilizer, a shovel, a garden rake, chemicals, vegetable seeds and a garden hose.
 
She joined SBPD in 2013. With her profits, Faimeaalii hopes to assist her family financially.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, a shovel, a garden rake, chemicals, vegetable seeds and a garden hose

loans.name: Apoiliu

texts.en:
Apoiliu is 38 years old and married with  no children.  She has a small garden where she grows cabbages, tomatoes, cucumber, eggplant, etc. that she can sell in her community or at the market. She has been doing this for two years. Apoiliu needs a loan to buy chemicals, vegetable seeds, fertilizer, a file,  a bushknife and a garden hose for her garden. 

She has been a member of SBPD since 2013. Apoiliu will use the profits from her sales to support her family.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, vegetable seeds, fertilizer, a file,  a bushknife and a garden hose

loans.name: Tumema

texts.en:
Tumema is a 48-year-old married woman with children. She has a small plantation that grows taro, taamu (a large root vegetable) and bananas to earn a living. She has been doing this for two years. 

Tumema has requested a loan to buy chemicals, bush knives, a digger and a weed sprayer. She has been a member of SBPD since 2009. With her profits, Tumema hopes to improve her housing.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, bush knives, a digger and a weed sprayer.

loans.name: Iutita

texts.en:
Iutita is a 20-year-old married woman with three children.
 
She has a small plantation and grows taros, bananas and yams to earn a living. She has been doing this for four years.

Iutita has requested a loan to buy chemicals,a backpack sprayer, barbed wire, bushknives and a rake. She has been a member of SBPD since 2013. With her profits, Iutita hopes to provide for her family's everyday needs and wants.

loans.use: to buy chemicals, a backpack sprayer, barbed wire, bushknives and a rake.

loans.name: Rarotoga

texts.en:
Rarotoga is a 55-year-old married woman with two children. 

She has a small plantation and grows taro, banana, etc. to earn a living. She has been doing this for more than five years. 

Rarotoga has requested a loan to buy a chain saw, chemicals, a backpack sprayer, taro root crops and a wheelbarrow. She has been a member of SPBD since 2010. With her profits, Rarotoga hopes to help improve her family's standard of living and meet their daily needs.

loans.use: to buy a chain saw, chemicals, a backpack sprayer, taro root crops and a wheelbarrow.

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah is 54 years old and married with three children.

Leah works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 8,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock for her sari-sari (general) store.

Leah has borrowed and repaid two loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for two years and also earns an income from tailoring.

Leah aspires to save enough money to build and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock for her sari-sari (general) store.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is 53 years old and married with five children. Three of her children are in school. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Teresita has a fishing business in the Philippines. Teresita requested a 8,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan amount through NWTF to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

Teresita has been in this business for 15 years. In the future, Teresita would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fishing gear and other equipment.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 30 years old and married with four children.

She earns a living by raising chickens and pigs in the Philippines. Agnes is borrowing 14,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF in order to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

Agnes has been raising chickens for three years and also earns additional income from pig fattening.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream to save enough money to expand her business and continue to send her children to school.

loans.use: to buy feeds and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Silvan

texts.en:
Silvan is a 39-year-old married father of three who resides with his family in Cogon, Ozamiz City. Silvan has a business selling a variety of fruits in the market, and he now needs additional capital to improve his offering to customers. He has requested a new loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC micro credit for this purpose.

The resulting additional profits will enable Silvan to save for the future education of his children. His plan is to eventually buy a motorcycle to use in the business.

loans.use: to buy more fruits to resell

loans.name: Gnambossou-Gbeta Group

texts.fr: Le groupe GNAMBOSSOU-GBETA est composé de deux personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. La représentante du groupe, nommée Sidoine (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 52 ans. Sidoine n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Sidoine est mariée à un certain Marcel. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Sidoine vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges de la maison. Pour ce faire, Sidoine vend divers produits (sucre, lait, savons...) à son domicile depuis dix sept ans. Sidoine s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité, Sidoine s’associe aux autres membres du groupe GNAMBOSSOU-GBETA pour solliciter un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: The group GNAMBOSSOU-GBETA is composed of two persons who reside in the same district. The group's representative, Sidoine (with her hand raised in the photo) is 52 years old. Sidoine did not attend school. She is married to a man named Marcel. The couple have two children, both in school and in their care. The couple jointly ensure that the various household expenses are covered. To do so, Sidoine has been selling a variety of goods (sugar, milk, soaps, …) at her home for seven years. She gets her supplies from a market in Benin. With the goal of bolstering her business, Sidoine joined with the other member of the group GNAMBOSSOU-GBETA to request a fourth loan from ALIDé. The previous loans were indeed repaid.

loans.use: to purchase various products (sugar, milk, soap,...)

loans.name: Norfely

texts.en:
Norfely is 54 years old, married and has four children.

Norfely works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines. She has been running the general store for ten years and also earns an income from rice farming and pig fattening. 

She requested a PHP 18,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more items like bread, biscuits, shampoo, sardines and other groceries. Norfely has borrowed and repaid five loans from NWTF before this loan. 

Norfely aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.
